content:
=== Game Rules ===
This is vgdl rule file:
BasicGame
  SpriteSet
    floor > Immovable randomtiling=0.9 img=oryx/floor3 hidden=True
    goal  > Door color=GREEN img=oryx/doorclosed1
    key   > Immovable color=ORANGE img=oryx/key2
    sword > OrientedFlicker limit=5 singleton=True img=oryx/slash1
    movable >
      avatar  > ShootAvatar   stype=sword frameRate=8
        nokey   > img=oryx/swordman1
        withkey > color=ORANGE img=oryx/swordmankey1
      enemy >  
        monsterQuick > RandomNPC cooldown=2 cons=6 img=oryx/bat1
        monsterNormal > RandomNPC cooldown=4 cons=8 img=oryx/spider2
        monsterSlow > RandomNPC cooldown=8 cons=12 img=oryx/scorpion1
      wall > Immovable autotiling=true img=oryx/wall3
      	

  LevelMapping
    g > floor goal
    + > floor key        
    A > floor nokey
    1 > floor monsterQuick
    2 > floor monsterNormal
    3 > floor monsterSlow
    w > wall
    . > floor
    

  InteractionSet
    movable wall  > stepBack
    nokey goal    > stepBack
    goal withkey  > killSprite scoreChange=1
    enemy sword > killSprite scoreChange=2
    enemy enemy > stepBack
    avatar enemy > killSprite scoreChange=-1
    nokey key     > transformTo stype=withkey scoreChange=1 killSecond=True

  TerminationSet
    SpriteCounter stype=goal   win=True
    SpriteCounter stype=avatar win=False
This is vgdl rule in natural language:
Here’s a plain‐English breakdown of what’s going on:

• Genre and Feel:
 – It’s a top‐down, tile‐based puzzle/action game with arcade elements.
 – You navigate a maze-like level with walls, floors, and various items while avoiding roaming monsters.

• Game Mechanics:
 – You control an avatar (a “ShootAvatar”) that can fire a short‐lived sword projectile.
 – The level has fixed walls and a randomly tiling floor.
 – There are a few key items: a key (orange) that you must collect and a door (green “goal”) that you must “open” to win.
 – There are two player states represented by “nokey” and “withkey.” If your character (initially in the nokey state) touches the key, it transforms into the “withkey” state—and you score a point.
 – When your “nokey” version comes in contact with the door, you get pushed back (it “steps back”), meaning you can’t pass without the key.
 – But if you’re in the “withkey” state and touch the door, the door is “killed” (i.e. removed) and you win (plus a little bonus score).
 – Enemies include several types of roaming monsters (Fast, Normal, and Slow) that move randomly. They also interact with one another by “stepping back” if they run into each other.
 – You also have a sword that can destroy enemies for extra points. If your sword touches an enemy, the enemy is removed from the field and you gain score.
 – Be careful: if your avatar comes into contact with an enemy normally, your avatar gets “killed” (losing points) and it triggers the loss condition.

• Objective and Win/Loss Conditions:
 – The goal is to remove the door sprite (by approaching it in the “withkey” state) which signifies winning.
 – If your avatar is ever eliminated (i.e. your sprite count for avatar drops to zero), you lose.
 – Scoring is mixed into the interactions, so while you’re aiming for victory, collecting points via key pickup and enemy kills is also part of the experience.

• Overall Strategy:
 – First, navigate the maze carefully to locate and collect the key. (Touching the key transforms your character from “nokey” to “withkey” and is absolutely vital.)
 – Use caution when moving through the level and avoid the roaming monsters. If necessary, use your sword projectile to eliminate some enemies.
 – Once you’ve acquired the key (i.e. are now “withkey”), head for the door. Because only your “withkey” state interacts properly with the door, bypassing the “step back” that happens with “nokey.”
 – Take advantage of the sword—aim and time your shots—to neutralize nearby foes so that your approach to the door is safer.
 – Maintain a good balance between offense (clearing enemies with your sword) and defense (steering clear of collision with monsters) to keep your avatar intact.
 – Watch out for the different speeds of the monsters (fast, normal, and slow) and plan your movement so you’re not caught off guard.
 – Once you touch the door in the “withkey” state, it will be removed, signaling the level’s completion and a win.

In summary, you want to safely explore the maze, get the key to change your state, use your sword wisely to handle monsters, and finally approach the door to finish the level without getting hit yourself. This mix of puzzle-solving (figuring out the safest path and key-door sequence) with arcade-style dodging and shooting makes for a dynamic and engaging experience.

You are an intelligent player playing a video game, and you have a friend provide you strategy. Interpret the state, rule, strategy and act accordingly. Notice that your avatar position is one of the most important information, if the position doesn't change from the last state, you need to analyze the state and make a different action from the last time.

=== Available Actions ===
0: ACTION_NIL
1: ACTION_USE
2: ACTION_LEFT
3: ACTION_RIGHT
4: ACTION_DOWN
5: ACTION_UP

=== High Level Plan === 


Evaluation: BAD
Feedback: Action "4" did not alter the state at all—there was no progress toward the goal, the move was ineffective (likely blocked or redundant), and it didn’t align with any clear strategic objective. This lack of impact resulted in a 0.0 reward from the environment.

Please understand the rule and the interaction set first, then locate the item, finally choose a meaningful action towards the win and respond in the format: ``` Action:<action number> ```. Include one sentence of feedback on the action and your expectation to see if it aligns with the strategy. Notice, Action 0 will not reasult in any change in this game environment, and you may need to understand the level layout first to play the game. 

=== Sprite Mapping ===
avatar -> 'a'
floor goal -> 'g'
floor key -> '+'
floor nokey -> 'A'
floor monsterQuick -> '1'
floor monsterNormal -> '2'
floor monsterSlow -> '3'
wall -> 'w'
floor -> '.'
goal -> '@'
key -> '#'
monsterNormal -> '$'
monsterQuick -> '%'
monsterSlow -> '&'
nokey -> '*'

=== Current State ===
=== Original State ===
wwwwwwwwwwwww
w..&.ww....*w
w....w......w
w.w.....wwwww
w#w........%w
w.w..wwwwwwww
w.......w...w
w...$w....w@w
wwwwwwwwwwwww

=== Rotated State (Y-axis emphasis) ===
wwwwwwwww
w...#...w
w..www..w
w......&w
w$......w
ww.w..www
w..w...ww
w..w....w
w.ww.w..w
w..w.w..w
ww.w.w..w
w@.w%w.*w
wwwwwwwww
Note: In the original state, each row corresponds to horizontal (left-right) layout in the game.
In the rotated version, each row corresponds to vertical (up-down) layout.=== Map in Natural language ===
Each line shows entity at (row, col).
In rotated version, row emphasizes vertical (up-down).
